cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:1

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The purpose of this chapter is to define confidential business information, outline the elements required for legal protection, and review the various factors courts use to establish those elements. The variable nature of business information makes it difficult to develop a precise definition. It may even be impossible to arrive at a final definition due to the fact that the potential subject-matter is limitless.[1] The English Court of Appeal case, Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler,[2] stated adamantly that:

It is clearly impossible to provide a list of matters which will qualify as trade secrets or their equivalent. Secret processes of manufacture provide obvious examples, but innumerable other pieces of information are capable of being trade secrets, though the secrecy of some information may be only short-lived.

See, for example, para. 10.11 of the Canadian Report on Trade Secrets. See also American Law Institute, Restatement of the Law of Torts (1939), which described the task as “impossible”. Many judges have made similar pronouncements: see, for example, Van Products Co. v. General Welding & Fabricating Co., 419 Pa. 248, 213 A.2d 769 (1965).
Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler, [1986] 1 All E.R. 617 (C.A.), at p. 627.
